'''Google Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}} and {{lse|GGEA}}) is an [[United States|American]] [[public company|public corporation]], specializing in [[Internet search]] and [[online advertising]]. The company is based in [[Mountain View, California]], and has 15,916 full-time employees (as of [[September 30]] [[2007]]).<ref>"[http://www.google.com/press/pressrel/revenues_q307.html Google Announces Third Quarter 2007 Results]." [[October 18]], [[2007]]. Retrieved on [[October 22]], [[2007]].</ref> Google's mission statement is, "to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful."<ref>"[http://www.google.com/corporate/ Google Corporate Information: Company Overview]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on [[January 6]], [[2007]].</ref> It is the largest American company (by [[market capitalization]]) that is not part of the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]].{{fact|date=December 2007}} Google's corporate philosophy includes statements such as "[[Don't be evil]]" and "Work should be challenging and the challenge should be fun", illustrating a somewhat relaxed corporate culture.
+
'''Google Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}} and {{lse|GGEA}}) is an [[United States|American]] [[public company|public corporation]], specializing in [[Internet search]] and [[online advertising]]. The company is based in [[Mountain View, California]], and has 15,916 full-time employees (as of [[September 30]] [[2007]]).<ref name=q32007results /> Google's mission statement is, "to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful."<ref>"[http://www.google.com/corporate/ Google Corporate Information: Company Overview]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on [[January 6]], [[2007]].</ref> It is the largest American company (by [[market capitalization]]) that is not part of the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]].{{fact|date=December 2007}} Google's corporate philosophy includes statements such as "[[Don't be evil]]" and "Work should be challenging and the challenge should be fun", illustrating a somewhat relaxed corporate culture.
Google was co-founded by [[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]] while they were students at [[Stanford University]] and the company was first incorporated as a [[privately held company]] on [[September 7]], [[1998]]. Google's [[initial public offering]] took place on [[August 19]], [[2004]], raising [[United States dollar|US$]]1.67 billion, making it worth US$23 billion. Through a series of new product developments, acquisitions and partnerships, the company has expanded its initial search and advertising business into other areas, including web-based [[email]], online mapping, office productivity, and video sharing, among others.
Google was co-founded by [[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]] while they were students at [[Stanford University]] and the company was first incorporated as a [[privately held company]] on [[September 7]], [[1998]]. Google's [[initial public offering]] took place on [[August 19]], [[2004]], raising [[United States dollar|US$]]1.67 billion, making it worth US$23 billion. Through a series of new product developments, acquisitions and partnerships, the company has expanded its initial search and advertising business into other areas, including web-based [[email]], online mapping, office productivity, and video sharing, among others.
Line 41: Line 41:
The first funding for Google as a company was secured in the form of a [[United States dollar|US$]]100,000 contribution from [[Andy Bechtolsheim]], co-founder of [[Sun Microsystems]], given to a corporation which did not yet exist.<ref name="Bechtolsheim">Kopytoff, Verne; Fost, Dan. "[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2004/04/29/MNGLD6CFND34.DTL For early Googlers, key word is $$$]." ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]].'' [[April 29]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> Around six months later, a much larger round of funding was announced, with the major investors being rival venture capital firms [[Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers]] and [[Sequoia Capital]].<ref name="Bechtolsheim" />
The first funding for Google as a company was secured in the form of a [[United States dollar|US$]]100,000 contribution from [[Andy Bechtolsheim]], co-founder of [[Sun Microsystems]], given to a corporation which did not yet exist.<ref name="Bechtolsheim">Kopytoff, Verne; Fost, Dan. "[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2004/04/29/MNGLD6CFND34.DTL For early Googlers, key word is $$$]." ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]].'' [[April 29]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> Around six months later, a much larger round of funding was announced, with the major investors being rival venture capital firms [[Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers]] and [[Sequoia Capital]].<ref name="Bechtolsheim" />
â
Google's initial public offering took place on [[August 19]], [[2004]]. 19,605,052 [[stock|shares]] were offered at a price of US$200 per share.<ref name="IPO">Elgin, Ben. "[http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/aug2004/tc20040819_6843_tc120.htm Google: Whiz Kids or Naughty Boys?]" ''[[Business Week]].'' [[August 19]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> Of that, 14,142,135 (another mathematical reference as [[square root of two|â2]] â 1.4142135) were floated by Google and 5,462,917 by selling stockholders. The sale raised US$1.67 billion, and gave Google a [[market capitalization]] of more than US$23 billion.<ref name="washpost">Webb, Cynthia L. "[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A14939-2004Aug19.html Google's IPO: Grate Expectations]." ''[[Washington Post]].'' [[August 19]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> The vast majority of Google's 271 million shares remained under Google's control. Many of Google's employees became instant [[paper millionaires]]. [[Yahoo!]], a competitor of Google, also benefited from the IPO because it owned 8.4 million shares of Google as of [[August 9]], [[2004]], ten days before the IPO.<ref name="yahooshares">Kuchinskas, Susan. "[http://www.internetnews.com/bus-news/article.php/3392781 Yahoo and Google Settle]." ''[http://www.internetnews.com/ internetnews.com].'' [[August 9]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref>
+
Google's initial public offering took place on [[August 19]], [[2004]]. 19,605,052 [[stock|shares]] were offered at a price of US$85 per share.<ref name="IPO">Elgin, Ben. "[http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/aug2004/tc20040819_6843_tc120.htm Google: Whiz Kids or Naughty Boys?]" ''[[Business Week]].'' [[August 19]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref><ref>http://investor.google.com/pdf/2004_AnnualReport.pdf</ref> Of that, 14,142,135 (another mathematical reference as [[square root of two|â2]] â 1.4142135) were floated by Google and 5,462,917 by selling stockholders. The sale raised US$1.67 billion, and gave Google a [[market capitalization]] of more than US$23 billion.<ref name="washpost">Webb, Cynthia L. "[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A14939-2004Aug19.html Google's IPO: Grate Expectations]." ''[[Washington Post]].'' [[August 19]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> The vast majority of Google's 271 million shares remained under Google's control. Many of Google's employees became instant [[paper millionaires]]. [[Yahoo!]], a competitor of Google, also benefited from the IPO because it owned 8.4 million shares of Google as of [[August 9]], [[2004]], ten days before the IPO.<ref name="yahooshares">Kuchinskas, Susan. "[http://www.internetnews.com/bus-news/article.php/3392781 Yahoo and Google Settle]." ''[http://www.internetnews.com/ internetnews.com].'' [[August 9]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref>
Google's post-IPO stock performance has been very good as well, with shares hitting US$700 for the first time on [[October 31]], [[2007]],<ref>[[Daily Telegraph]] Issue 47,409 Business Section Page B5 date, [[7 November]], [[2007]]</ref> due to strong sales and earnings in the advertising market, as well as the release of new features such as the [[Google Desktop|desktop search function]] and personalized home page.<ref name="bowlingforgoogle">La Monica, Paul R. "[http://money.cnn.com/2005/05/25/technology/techinvestor/lamonica/index.htm Bowling for Google]." ''[[CNN]].'' [[May 25]], [[2005]]. Retrieved on [[February 28]] [[2007]].</ref> The surge in stock price is fueled primarily by individual investors, as opposed to large institutional investors and [[mutual fund]]s.<ref name="bowlingforgoogle" />
Google's post-IPO stock performance has been very good as well, with shares hitting US$700 for the first time on [[October 31]], [[2007]],<ref>[[Daily Telegraph]] Issue 47,409 Business Section Page B5 date, [[7 November]], [[2007]]</ref> due to strong sales and earnings in the advertising market, as well as the release of new features such as the [[Google Desktop|desktop search function]] and personalized home page.<ref name="bowlingforgoogle">La Monica, Paul R. "[http://money.cnn.com/2005/05/25/technology/techinvestor/lamonica/index.htm Bowling for Google]." ''[[CNN]].'' [[May 25]], [[2005]]. Retrieved on [[February 28]] [[2007]].</ref> The surge in stock price is fueled primarily by individual investors, as opposed to large institutional investors and [[mutual fund]]s.<ref name="bowlingforgoogle" />
